questions.text: An investigator is studying bacterial toxins in a nonpathogenic bacterial monoculture that has been inoculated with specific bacteriophages. These phages were previously cultured in a toxin-producing bacterial culture. After inoculation, a new toxin is isolated from the culture. Genetic sequencing shows that the bacteria have incorporated viral genetic information, including the gene for this toxin, into their genome. The described process is most likely responsible for acquired pathogenicity in which of the following bacteria?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus acquires resistance to antibiotics such as vancomycin through transposition. The Tn1546 transposon moves from plasmid encoding vancomycin resistance in Enterococcus (VRE) to S. aureus during coinfection. Genes coding bacterial toxins are usually transferred by a different mechanism.
Image Description:

Bacterial transposition is a process by which genetic information is exchanged between bacteria or within the genome of the same bacterium via transposons.

Transposons (transposable elements or jumping genes) are DNA segments that can be excised from one location of the genome and re-inserted into another, thereby altering genetic expression (e.g., antibiotic resistance). Their action is brought about by transposase enzymes.

First step: The transposase enzyme binds to inverted repeat sequences (IR) flanking the transposons.
Second step: Transposase catalyzes the excision of the transposon sequence from the bacterial genome.
Third step: The target insertion site is recognized by transposase enzymes, which also catalyze the re-insertion of the transposon at this site.

B) CORRECT:

Nontoxigenic strains of Corynebacterium diphtheriae can acquire the gene that encodes the diphtheria toxin through specialized transduction. This occurs when a toxigenic C. diphtheriae is infected with a lysogenic bacteriophage and the viral genome is inserted into the bacterial genome. As the phage replicates and excises its own nucleic acids from the bacterial genome to produce new phages, the flanking bacterial toxin gene is also copied to the new viruses. Any subsequent nontoxigenic bacteria infected with these phages will then acquire a copy of the toxin gene, which has become part of the phage genome. The genes for many other bacterial toxins such as erythrogenic exotoxin A, botulinum toxin, cholera toxin, and Shiga toxin are also transferred by specialized transduction.
Image Description:

Bacterial transduction is the process of gene transfer between bacteria via bacteriophages.

Top panel: generalized transduction (lytic cycle via virulent phages)
A bacteriophage attaches itself to the bacterial cell wall and injects its DNA into the bacterium. The viral DNA replicates within the infected bacterium and is incorporated into protein shells (phage capsids) to form numerous bacteriophages. The new bacteriophages lyse the bacterial cell wall and are released to infect other bacteria in the surrounding environment. A section of the bacterial genome may be incorporated into a viral capsid and be transferred to another bacterium, forming a recombinant bacterium. As any portion of the bacterial genome may be transferred, in a process known as generalized transduction.

Bottom panel: specialized transduction (lysogenic and lytic cycle via temperate phages)
Once the bacteriophage has injected its DNA into the bacterium, the viral DNA is incorporated into the bacterial genome at a specific location and remains inactive as a prophage (lysogenic phase). Upon activation (e.g., with heat or UV radiation), the viral DNA replicates, is incorporated into phage capsids, and is released into the surrounding environment through lysing of the host bacterial cell wall (lytic phase). During this process, the bacterial DNA flanking the viral DNA is also incorporated into the viral capsid and transferred to another bacterium, forming a recombinant bacterium. Because a specific portion of the bacterial genome is being transferred, the process is known as specialized transduction.

The panel on the right summarizes the major difference between generalized and specialized transduction.

C) INCORRECT:

Haemophilus influenzae acquires virulence factors through bacterial transformation, in which exogenous genetic material is taken up and expressed. Bacterial transformation is not dependent on the presence or absence of bacteriophages.
Image Description:

Transformation is a type of gene transfer in which extracellular genetic material is taken up by a competent bacterium that then incorporates the new DNA fragment into its own genome and expresses new genes.
Only competent bacteria can undergo transformation, as their cell wall is permeable to extracellular DNA.
A non-competent bacterium can become competent under natural conditions (e.g., starvation) or through laboratory interventions (e.g., heat shock or chemical treatment).
The extracellular genetic material may be free DNA from a dead bacterium that has lysed (panel a), or a plasmid (panel b).

Natural transformation occurs in some bacterial species (e.g., Neisseria, Hemophilus) and artificial transformation is used in genetic engineering (i.e., in recombinant technology).

D) INCORRECT:

Neisseria meningitidis acquires virulence factors through bacterial transformation, in which exogenous genetic material is taken up and expressed. Bacterial transformation is not dependent on the presence or absence of bacteriophages.
Image Description:

Transformation is a type of gene transfer in which extracellular genetic material is taken up by a competent bacterium that then incorporates the new DNA fragment into its own genome and expresses new genes.
Only competent bacteria can undergo transformation, as their cell wall is permeable to extracellular DNA.
A non-competent bacterium can become competent under natural conditions (e.g., starvation) or through laboratory interventions (e.g., heat shock or chemical treatment).
The extracellular genetic material may be free DNA from a dead bacterium that has lysed (panel a), or a plasmid (panel b).

Natural transformation occurs in some bacterial species (e.g., Neisseria, Hemophilus) and artificial transformation is used in genetic engineering (i.e., in recombinant technology).

E) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae acquire virulence factors through bacterial transformation, in which exogenous genetic material is taken up and expressed. Bacterial transformation is not dependent on the presence or absence of bacteriophages.
Image Description:

Transformation is a type of gene transfer in which extracellular genetic material is taken up by a competent bacterium that then incorporates the new DNA fragment into its own genome and expresses new genes.
Only competent bacteria can undergo transformation, as their cell wall is permeable to extracellular DNA.
A non-competent bacterium can become competent under natural conditions (e.g., starvation) or through laboratory interventions (e.g., heat shock or chemical treatment).
The extracellular genetic material may be free DNA from a dead bacterium that has lysed (panel a), or a plasmid (panel b).

Natural transformation occurs in some bacterial species (e.g., Neisseria, Hemophilus) and artificial transformation is used in genetic engineering (i.e., in recombinant technology).
questions.hint: The virus has infected the previously nonpathogenic bacteria and incorporated its own viral genetic information into the bacterial genome, giving the bacteria a new virulence factor. This process is called specialized transduction.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man hospitalized for acute pancreatitis develops a high-grade fever and productive cough with thick sputum. Medical history is significant for alcohol use disorder. A sample of expectorated sputum is obtained and fixed to a microscope slide using heat. Crystal violet is applied to the slide, followed by iodine, then acetone, and lastly, safranin. A photomicrograph of the result is shown. Which of the following properties of this bacteria's cell wall is responsible for the color seen on staining?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The amount of peptidoglycan in the bacterial cell wall determines whether the Gram stain will be positive or negative. Gram-positive species, which have a thick peptidoglycan layer, retain the crystal violet and appear deep purple. Gram-negative species have a thin peptidoglycan layer and do not retain the crystal violet after washing with alcohol or acetone. Instead, lipopolysaccharides on the outer membrane of gram-negative organisms stain pink after the application of the counterstain (e.g., safranin, carbol fuchsin).

B) INCORRECT:

Lipopolysaccharides are a major component of the outer membrane of gram-negative bacteria. During Gram staining, lipopolysaccharides stain pink after the application of the counterstain.

C) INCORRECT:

Transmembrane lipoproteins (also known as proteolipids) are present in the bacterial cell membrane and are involved in signal transduction, molecular transport, bacterial conjugation, and cellular adhesion. However, these molecules are not responsible for the color seen on Gram staining.

D) INCORRECT:

Mycolic acid, which is a component of the cell wall in acid-fast bacilli (e.g., Mycobacterium spp., Nocardia spp.), stains pink-red on Ziehl-Neelsen staining and red-yellow on auramine-rhodamine staining. This scenario, however, describes Gram staining and the cell wall of K. pneumoniae does not contain mycolic acid.

E) INCORRECT:

Lipoteichoic acid, which is a cell wall component that acts as an antigen for Toll-like receptors, is present in gram-positive but not gram-negative bacteria.
questions.hint: This process is Gram staining. High-grade fever, productive cough, and alcohol use disorder, in conjunction with pink (gram-negative) rods on Gram staining, suggest infection with Klebsiella pneumoniae.

questions.text: An investigator is studying bacterial adaptations to the environment in an infectious isolate and a noninfectious isolate of Hemophilus influenzae type B. Animals exposed to the noninfectious isolate do not develop symptoms of infection. The investigator cultivates the noninfectious isolate in a culture with lysed bacteria from the infectious isolate. Some of the animals exposed to these bacteria develop symptoms of infection. Which of the following processes is most likely responsible for the described findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bacterial transposition is a process in which DNA from one location in the genome is excised and then reintegrated into a different location. This process can transfer genes between plasmids and chromosomes. It does not describe the transfer of genetic material from one bacterial isolate to another as seen in this experiment.
Image Description:

Bacterial transposition is a process by which genetic information is exchanged between bacteria or within the genome of the same bacterium via transposons.

Transposons (transposable elements or jumping genes) are DNA segments that can be excised from one location of the genome and re-inserted into another, thereby altering genetic expression (e.g., antibiotic resistance). Their action is brought about by transposase enzymes.

First step: The transposase enzyme binds to inverted repeat sequences (IR) flanking the transposons.
Second step: Transposase catalyzes the excision of the transposon sequence from the bacterial genome.
Third step: The target insertion site is recognized by transposase enzymes, which also catalyze the re-insertion of the transposon at this site.

B) INCORRECT:

Specialized transduction is a process in which bacterial DNA is transferred from one bacterium to another bacterium via a bacteriophage. A lysogenic bacteriophage infects a bacterium and inserts viral DNA into the bacterial chromosome. When this DNA is excised to make new viral particles, nearby bacterial genes are incorporated into the bacteriophage capsid. The bacteriophage then lyses the infected bacterium and can transfer fragments of genetic material when it infects a new bacterium. Bacteriophages are not used in this experiment.
Image Description:

Bacterial transduction is the process of gene transfer between bacteria via bacteriophages.

Top panel: generalized transduction (lytic cycle via virulent phages)
A bacteriophage attaches itself to the bacterial cell wall and injects its DNA into the bacterium. The viral DNA replicates within the infected bacterium and is incorporated into protein shells (phage capsids) to form numerous bacteriophages. The new bacteriophages lyse the bacterial cell wall and are released to infect other bacteria in the surrounding environment. A section of the bacterial genome may be incorporated into a viral capsid and be transferred to another bacterium, forming a recombinant bacterium. As any portion of the bacterial genome may be transferred, in a process known as generalized transduction.

Bottom panel: specialized transduction (lysogenic and lytic cycle via temperate phages)
Once the bacteriophage has injected its DNA into the bacterium, the viral DNA is incorporated into the bacterial genome at a specific location and remains inactive as a prophage (lysogenic phase). Upon activation (e.g., with heat or UV radiation), the viral DNA replicates, is incorporated into phage capsids, and is released into the surrounding environment through lysing of the host bacterial cell wall (lytic phase). During this process, the bacterial DNA flanking the viral DNA is also incorporated into the viral capsid and transferred to another bacterium, forming a recombinant bacterium. Because a specific portion of the bacterial genome is being transferred, the process is known as specialized transduction.

The panel on the right summarizes the major difference between generalized and specialized transduction.

C) INCORRECT:

Bacterial conjugation is a process in which a bacteria with a plasmid (F+) forms a sex pilus and transfers genetic material to a bacterium that lacks a plasmid (F-). This process of genetic exchange requires intact cells, not lysed cells as used in this experiment.
Image Description:

Conjugation is a process of gene transfer from one bacterium to another that occurs through direct contact via a sex pilus.

Top right: F factor is a plasmid that encodes genes for sex pili. F+ bacteria (donor) contain the F factor plasmid and F- bacteria (recipient) do not.

Left: The F plasmid in an F+ bacterium initiates the growth of the sex pilus that connects to an F- bacterium, forming a bridge between the two bacteria (mating pair).

Center: A strand of the F plasmid is transferred to the F- bacterium through the bridge.

Right: Each bacterium now has a single strand of F plasmid that creates a complementary copy of itself, resulting in two F+ bacteria, each with its own F plasmid.

D) INCORRECT:

Genetic reassortment occurs with viruses, not bacteria. Viral reassortment can occur when two or more distinct viral strains with segmented genomes coinfect one cell. New viral particles are assembled with genetic segments that originated from different viral strains. Thus, they contain significantly different combinations of genes from the original viral strains.

E) CORRECT:

Bacterial transformation is a process in which bacteria take up naked DNA (e.g., from lysis of bacteria) through the cell membrane, incorporate the DNA into their genome, and express new genes. Several species of bacteria can carry out this process, including S. pneumoniae, Neisseria spp., and H. influenzae type b, as seen in this experiment.
Image Description:

Transformation is a type of gene transfer in which extracellular genetic material is taken up by a competent bacterium that then incorporates the new DNA fragment into its own genome and expresses new genes.
Only competent bacteria can undergo transformation, as their cell wall is permeable to extracellular DNA.
A non-competent bacterium can become competent under natural conditions (e.g., starvation) or through laboratory interventions (e.g., heat shock or chemical treatment).
The extracellular genetic material may be free DNA from a dead bacterium that has lysed (panel a), or a plasmid (panel b).

Natural transformation occurs in some bacterial species (e.g., Neisseria, Hemophilus) and artificial transformation is used in genetic engineering (i.e., in recombinant technology).

F) INCORRECT:

Generalized transduction is a process in which bacterial DNA is transferred from one bacterium to another bacterium via a bacteriophage. A lytic bacteriophage infects a bacterium and cleaves bacterial DNA, which becomes packaged in the bacteriophage capsid. When the bacteriophage then infects another bacterium, it can transfer the DNA. Bacteriophages are not used in this experiment.
Image Description:

Bacterial transduction is the process of gene transfer between bacteria via bacteriophages.

Top panel: generalized transduction (lytic cycle via virulent phages)
A bacteriophage attaches itself to the bacterial cell wall and injects its DNA into the bacterium. The viral DNA replicates within the infected bacterium and is incorporated into protein shells (phage capsids) to form numerous bacteriophages. The new bacteriophages lyse the bacterial cell wall and are released to infect other bacteria in the surrounding environment. A section of the bacterial genome may be incorporated into a viral capsid and be transferred to another bacterium, forming a recombinant bacterium. As any portion of the bacterial genome may be transferred, in a process known as generalized transduction.

Bottom panel: specialized transduction (lysogenic and lytic cycle via temperate phages)
Once the bacteriophage has injected its DNA into the bacterium, the viral DNA is incorporated into the bacterial genome at a specific location and remains inactive as a prophage (lysogenic phase). Upon activation (e.g., with heat or UV radiation), the viral DNA replicates, is incorporated into phage capsids, and is released into the surrounding environment through lysing of the host bacterial cell wall (lytic phase). During this process, the bacterial DNA flanking the viral DNA is also incorporated into the viral capsid and transferred to another bacterium, forming a recombinant bacterium. Because a specific portion of the bacterial genome is being transferred, the process is known as specialized transduction.

The panel on the right summarizes the major difference between generalized and specialized transduction.

G) INCORRECT:

Genetic recombination occurs with viruses, not bacteria. Viral recombination can occur when two distinct viral strains coinfect one cell. The viruses then exchange fragments of genetic material that share significant homology between their genetic sequences.
questions.hint: Bacterial lysis releases naked DNA that can be taken up by other bacteria. Through this process, nonvirulent types of Hemophilus influenzae can obtain genes that encode the bacterial capsule, which allows the bacteria to become virulent.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of fevers, chills, and left lower quadrant pain. Her temperature is 39.1C (102.3F), pulse is 126/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. There is blood oozing around the site of a peripheral intravenous line. Pelvic examination shows mucopurulent discharge from the cervical os and left adnexal tenderness. Laboratory studies show:


Platelet count
14,200/mm3



Fibrinogen

83 mg/mL (N = 200430 mg/dL)


D-dimer

965 ng/mL (N < 500 ng/mL)


When phenol is applied to a sample of the patient's blood at 90C, a phosphorylated N-acetylglucosamine dimer with 6 fatty acids attached to a polysaccharide side chain is identified. A blood culture is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Coagulase-positive, gram-positive cocci forming mauve-colored colonies on methicillin-containing agar
Encapsulated, gram-negative coccobacilli forming grey-colored colonies on charcoal blood agar
Spore-forming, gram-positive bacilli forming yellow colonies on casein agar
Lactose-fermenting, gram-negative rods forming pink colonies on MacConkey agar
Gamma-hemolytic, gram-positive cocci forming green colonies on vancomycin agar

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) produces toxic shock syndrome toxin 1 (TSST1), a superantigen that cross-links major histocompatibility complex class II molecules with T-cell receptors on antigen-presenting cells, which results in polyclonal T cell activation and a massive release of cytokines. This causes toxic shock syndrome, which manifests with fever and a desquamating rash that can rapidly progress to shock and end-organ failure. MRSA bacteremia would not account for the presence of lipopolysaccharide in this patient's serum.

B) INCORRECT:

Bordetella pertussis secretes pertussis toxin. Although the cell membrane of Bordetella pertussis has a lipopolysaccharide (LPS) component, it is structurally different from the LPS of most other gram-negative species. This difference is thought to be an important feature of the pathogenesis of whooping cough but also a limiting factor in the bacteria's ability to inoculate the serum and cause sepsis. It is therefore unlikely that this pathogen would be isolated from this patient's blood culture.

C) INCORRECT:

Clostridium botulinum secretes the exotoxin botulinum toxin responsible for causing botulism. Infection with C. botulinum would not explain this patient's presentation with localized abdominal pain and DIC. Furthermore, the presence of this bacteria would not account for the lipopolysaccharide detected in the patient's serum.

D) CORRECT:

Escherichia coli is a lactose-fermenting, gram-negative rod that grows as pink colonies on MacConkey agar. Like all gram-negative organisms, its outer cellular membrane is composed of lipopolysaccharide, which is also known as endotoxin. The lipid A component of endotoxin activates tissue factor, the complement system, and macrophages, resulting in fever, hypotension, and DIC. In light of this patient's left lower quadrant pain with mucopurulent discharge from the cervix, a tubo-ovarian abscess (TOA) is the most likely source of the E. coli bacteremia.

E) INCORRECT:

Infection with Enterococcus faecalis most often presents with endocarditis, urinary tract infection, or sepsis. E. faecalis secretes exotoxins such as cytolysin, but lipopolysaccharide is not associated with E. faecalis. It is therefore unlikely that this pathogen would be isolated from this patient's blood culture.
questions.hint: This woman's fever, tachycardia, and hypotension suggest septic shock, and her laboratory studies (low fibrinogen, elevated D-dimer, and thrombocytopenia) indicate that she has also developed disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). The identification of a phosphorylated N-acetylglucosamine dimer with fatty acids attached to a polysaccharide side chain indicates the presence of an organism with a lipopolysaccharide (LPS) endotoxin.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department shortly after sustaining injuries in a building fire. On arrival, he appears agitated and has shortness of breath. Examination shows multiple second-degree burns over the chest and abdomen and third-degree burns over the upper extremities. Treatment with intravenous fluids and analgesics is begun. Two days later, the patient is confused. His temperature is 36C (96.8F), pulse is 125/min, and blood pressure is 100/58 mm Hg. Examination shows violaceous discoloration and edema of the burn wounds. His leukocyte count is 16,000/mm3. Blood cultures grow gram-negative, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting rods. The causal organism actively secretes a virulence factor that acts primarily via which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phagocytosis can be inhibited by the pertussis toxin, which is actively secreted by Bordetella pertussis, a gram-negative, oxidase-positive coccobacillus. B. pertussis causes fever, paroxysmal cough, and posttussive vomiting in unimmunized children but does not infect burn wounds. Components of certain bacteria (e.g., mucoid polysaccharide capsule of Pseudomonas aeruginosa) also inhibit phagocytosis. However, these are structural components that are not actively secreted.

B) INCORRECT:

The overwhelming release of cytokines (e.g., IL-1, IL-6, TNF-) can be induced by endotoxins from gram-negative bacteria and by superantigens (e.g., TSST-1 of Staphylococcus aureus, erythrogenic exotoxin A of Streptococcus pyogenes). The release of endotoxins from Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is the organism infecting this patient's burns, is most likely responsible for the features of septic shock (hypotension, tachycardia, confusion, leukocytosis). However, endotoxins are released by bacterial cell lysis and are not actively secreted.

C) INCORRECT:

Fluid secretion from cells can be increased by exotoxins that elevate cAMP levels (e.g., heat-labile toxin of enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli, edema toxin of Bacillus anthracis, cholera toxin of Vibrio cholerae). E. coli is a gram-negative rod, and certain strains can infect burn wounds and result in septic shock, as seen here. However, E. coli is also an oxidase-negative, lactose-fermenting organism. Moreover, the exotoxin-producing strains of E. coli (ETEC) typically cause diarrhea and not burn wound infections.

D) CORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa secretes exotoxin A, which inactivates elongation factor-2 (EF-2) by ADP-ribosylation. Since EF-2 facilitates the translocation of the growing peptide from the A site to the P site of eukaryotic ribosomes, deactivation of EF-2 causes inhibition of protein synthesis. P. aeruginosa also produces phospholipase C, which degrades cell membranes. Together, these toxins enable P. aeruginosa to infect burn wounds and cause local necrosis. This patient's features of septic shock (hypotension, tachycardia, confusion, leukocytosis) are most likely caused by the endotoxins produced by P. aeruginosa. However, endotoxins are released by bacterial lysis and are not actively secreted.

The diphtheria toxin produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae also inactivates EF-2. Other exotoxins that inhibit protein synthesis are the Shiga toxin of Shigella spp. and Shiga-like toxin of enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli, which deadenylate the 60S subunit of eukaryotic rRNA.

E) INCORRECT:

The release of neurotransmitters can be inhibited by the Clostridium tetani exotoxin, which inhibits glycine and GABA release, and by the Clostridium botulinum exotoxin, which inhibits acetylcholine release. C. tetani, a non-lactose fermenting rod, often infects burn wounds. This is the rationale for administering the tetanus vaccine or the tetanus immune globulin in patients with burns. However, C. tetani is a gram-positive, oxidase-negative organism that typically causes spastic paralysis, which is not seen here.
questions.hint: Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a gram-negative, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting rod, is an important cause of burn wound infections. A virulence factor that is actively secreted by an organism is called an exotoxin.

questions.text: An investigator studying mechanisms of acquired antibiotic resistance in bacteria conducts a study using isolated strains of Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus. The E. coli strain harbors plasmid pRK212.1, which conveys resistance to kanamycin. The S. aureus strain is susceptible to kanamycin. Both bacterial strains are mixed in a liquid growth medium containing deoxyribonuclease. After incubation for 2 days and subsequent transfer to a solid medium, the S. aureus colonies show no lysis in response to the application of kanamycin. Analysis of chromosomal DNA from the kanamycin-resistant S. aureus strain does not reveal the kanamycin-resistance gene. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The horizontal transfer of resistance genes can occur via bacterial transformation, which involves the uptake of free fragments of DNA. However, deoxyribonuclease in the growth medium would degrade any free DNA segments that are released following the death of the kanamycin-resistant E. coli strain. A different mechanism of horizontal gene transfer is responsible for kanamycin resistance in S. aureus.
Image Description:

Transformation is a type of gene transfer in which extracellular genetic material is taken up by a competent bacterium that then incorporates the new DNA fragment into its own genome and expresses new genes.
Only competent bacteria can undergo transformation, as their cell wall is permeable to extracellular DNA.
A non-competent bacterium can become competent under natural conditions (e.g., starvation) or through laboratory interventions (e.g., heat shock or chemical treatment).
The extracellular genetic material may be free DNA from a dead bacterium that has lysed (panel a), or a plasmid (panel b).

Natural transformation occurs in some bacterial species (e.g., Neisseria, Hemophilus) and artificial transformation is used in genetic engineering (i.e., in recombinant technology).

B) CORRECT:

Bacterial conjugation, the transfer of genetic material from one bacterium to another across a sex pilus (mating bridge), is a mechanism for the horizontal transfer of antibiotic-resistance genes. The resistance-conferring plasmid (R-plasmid) usually also contains fertility factor (F factor) genes, which enable the donor bacterium to form a sex pilus. In F+ x F- conjugation, as seen here, a single strand of the R-plasmid is transferred to the recipient, while the complementary strand remains in the donor. Both bacteria then make complimentary copies of the single-stranded R-plasmid, which makes them resistant to the antibiotic as well as capable of producing sex pili and transferring the R-plasmid to other bacteria. In Hfr x F- conjugation, the R-plasmid is first incorporated into a region of the donor bacterium's chromosome to form a high-frequency recombination (Hfr) cell. Subsequently, a part of a single strand of the R-plasmid along with some flanking bacterial chromosomal DNA is transferred to the recipient, which can acquire antibiotic resistance in this manner but is incapable of producing sex pili.
Image Description:

Conjugation is a process of gene transfer from one bacterium to another that occurs through direct contact via a sex pilus.

Top right: F factor is a plasmid that encodes genes for sex pili. F+ bacteria (donor) contain the F factor plasmid and F- bacteria (recipient) do not.

Left: The F plasmid in an F+ bacterium initiates the growth of the sex pilus that connects to an F- bacterium, forming a bridge between the two bacteria (mating pair).

Center: A strand of the F plasmid is transferred to the F- bacterium through the bridge.

Right: Each bacterium now has a single strand of F plasmid that creates a complementary copy of itself, resulting in two F+ bacteria, each with its own F plasmid.

C) INCORRECT:

Bacterial transposition is the exchange of genetic information via transposons (jumping genes). Transposons carrying resistance genes (e.g., Tn1546 carrying the vancomycin-resistance gene vanA) can transfer from chromosomal DNA to plasmids and vice versa. However, transposons are not able to jump directly from one bacterium to another; an intermediate step of horizontal gene transfer needs to occur before transposition. Moreover, the analysis of chromosomal DNA from the kanamycin-resistant S. aureus strain does not reveal the kanamycin-resistance gene. This indicates that no transposition occurred.
Image Description:

Bacterial transposition is a process by which genetic information is exchanged between bacteria or within the genome of the same bacterium via transposons.

Transposons (transposable elements or jumping genes) are DNA segments that can be excised from one location of the genome and re-inserted into another, thereby altering genetic expression (e.g., antibiotic resistance). Their action is brought about by transposase enzymes.

First step: The transposase enzyme binds to inverted repeat sequences (IR) flanking the transposons.
Second step: Transposase catalyzes the excision of the transposon sequence from the bacterial genome.
Third step: The target insertion site is recognized by transposase enzymes, which also catalyze the re-insertion of the transposon at this site.

D) INCORRECT:

Bacterial secretion is not a mechanism of bacterial DNA transfer. Instead, it is a process that facilitates the direct delivery of virulence factors (e.g., toxins) from certain gram-negative bacteria (e.g., Pseudomonas, Yersinia, Shigella, Salmonella, E. coli) to eukaryotic host cells via injectisomes.

E) INCORRECT:

The horizontal transfer of resistance genes can occur via bacterial transduction. However, transduction is the transfer of bacterial DNA from one bacterium to another via infection with a bacteriophage (i.e., virally-mediated transfer), which does not occur in this experiment.
Image Description:

Bacterial transduction is the process of gene transfer between bacteria via bacteriophages.

Top panel: generalized transduction (lytic cycle via virulent phages)
A bacteriophage attaches itself to the bacterial cell wall and injects its DNA into the bacterium. The viral DNA replicates within the infected bacterium and is incorporated into protein shells (phage capsids) to form numerous bacteriophages. The new bacteriophages lyse the bacterial cell wall and are released to infect other bacteria in the surrounding environment. A section of the bacterial genome may be incorporated into a viral capsid and be transferred to another bacterium, forming a recombinant bacterium. As any portion of the bacterial genome may be transferred, in a process known as generalized transduction.

Bottom panel: specialized transduction (lysogenic and lytic cycle via temperate phages)
Once the bacteriophage has injected its DNA into the bacterium, the viral DNA is incorporated into the bacterial genome at a specific location and remains inactive as a prophage (lysogenic phase). Upon activation (e.g., with heat or UV radiation), the viral DNA replicates, is incorporated into phage capsids, and is released into the surrounding environment through lysing of the host bacterial cell wall (lytic phase). During this process, the bacterial DNA flanking the viral DNA is also incorporated into the viral capsid and transferred to another bacterium, forming a recombinant bacterium. Because a specific portion of the bacterial genome is being transferred, the process is known as specialized transduction.

The panel on the right summarizes the major difference between generalized and specialized transduction.
questions.hint: The transfer of the pRK212.1 kanamycin-resistance plasmid from one bacterium to another (horizontal gene transfer) was most likely achieved via the production of a sex pilus.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus is admitted to the hospital because of a 2-day history of fever, breathlessness, and cough productive of large quantities of green sputum. She drinks 8 beers daily. Her temperature is 39C (102.2F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Blood and sputum cultures grow gram-negative, catalase-positive, capsulated bacilli. Which of the following components of the causal organism is the most likely cause of this patient's hypotension?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lecithinase, a phospholipase, is one of the virulence factors of P. aeruginosa. However, it causes degradation of cell membranes and is responsible for edema and tissue necrosis rather than septic shock and hypotension.

B) INCORRECT:

Lipooligosaccharide (LOS) is an endotoxin that is part of the capsular structure of some gram-negative bacteria including Neisseria meningitidis. It can be responsible for the hypotension associated with septic shock. However, N. meningitidis is a gram-negative, catalase-negative diplococcus. The most likely pathogen responsible for this patient's bacteremia and hypotension is P. aeruginosa, a gram-negative bacillus that does not have LOS.

C) INCORRECT:

Poly-D-glutamate is a polypeptide molecule that forms the capsular component of Bacillus anthracis and allows the pathogen to evade immune defense and phagocytosis. B. anthracis is not known to cause septic shock. Furthermore, it is a gram-positive, spore-forming rod, while the most likely pathogen responsible for this patient's bacteremia and hypotension is P. aeruginosa, a gram-negative bacillus.

D) INCORRECT:

Teichoic acid is part of the phospholipid bilayer and cell wall of many gram-positive bacteria. By activating TNF- and IL-1, teichoic acid can trigger gram-positive-induced septic shock and hypotension. However, the most likely pathogen responsible for this patient's bacteremia and hypotension is P. aeruginosa, a gram-negative pathogen that does not have teichoic acid.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's hypotension is most likely the result of septic shock due to Pseudomonas bacteremia. Lipid A, an endotoxin present in the lipopolysaccharide of many gram-negative bacterial cell walls, is responsible for hypotension in gram-negative bacteremia. Upon release from the bacterial cell wall, lipid A causes activation of macrophages and the complement cascade via TNF-, IL-1, and IL-6, resulting in the release of additional inflammatory mediators, including nitric oxide and histamine. These mediators cause relaxation of the smooth muscles, inducing vasodilation and hypotension, as seen in this patient.
questions.hint: Fever, hypotension, tachycardia, and increased respiratory rate are consistent with sepsis, likely due to pneumonia (as evidenced by productive cough, fever, and breathlessness). This patient's history of diabetes mellitus and excessive alcohol consumption is suggestive of Pseudomonas aeruginosa bacteremia, which is consistent with the culture findings.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of low-grade fevers and a cough lasting for 2 weeks. He has vomited several times after fits of coughing. He has no history of serious illness and has not received any routine childhood vaccinations. His temperature is 38.3C (101F). Physical examination shows erythema of the nasal and oral mucosa. While in the exam room, he has a long series of consecutive coughs, during which he appears diaphoretic. The coughing is followed by a loud inspiratory gasp. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 16,300/mm3 (67% lymphocytes). The pathogen most likely responsible for this patient's presentation contains a toxin that acts by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Pertussis toxin is an important virulence factor of Bordetella pertussis. This AB exotoxin binds to the surface of host cells and enters them by endocytosis. Inside the cytosol, pertussis toxin catalyzes the ADP-ribosylation of the subunit of Gi proteins, which prevents their interaction with G protein-coupled receptors and thus impairs inhibition of adenylate cyclase activity. The resultant accumulation of cAMP disrupts cellular signaling pathways and causes various pathological effects in host cells. This includes the modulation of the host immune response, e.g., the inhibition of neutrophil migration. Pertussis toxin also causes several systemic manifestations associated with whooping cough, such as lymphocytosis.

See Overview of exotoxins table.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevation of intracellular cGMP via the overactivation of guanylate cyclase is the action mechanism of heat-stable toxins produced by enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC). The elevation inhibits the reabsorption of salt and water by enterocytes, leading to watery diarrhea. However, it does not produce respiratory symptoms as seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

The inactivation of host cells' elongation factor 2 (EF-2) via ADP-ribosylation is the action mechanism of both exotoxin A, which is produced by P. aeruginosa, and diphtheria toxin, which is secreted by C. diphtheriae. These exotoxins inhibit protein translation and result in cell death and necrosis. Although this patient presents with fever and cough, other symptoms of diphtheria (e.g., a grayish pharyngeal and tonsillar pseudomembrane, bull neck due to cervical lymphadenopathy, and myocarditis) are not present, which makes this diagnosis unlikely. Without prior hospitalization and no sign of pneumonia (e.g., crackles on auscultation, malaise, high fever, and chills), nosocomial pneumonia caused by P. aeruginosa is also unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

The inactivation of the 60S subunit in host cells' ribosomes is the action mechanism of Shiga toxin (produced by Shigella) and Shiga-like toxin (produced by enterohemorrhagic E. coli; EHEC). Both of these cleave adenine in rRNA (ribosomal RNA), which causes enterocyte damage and bloody diarrhea. Neither Shigella nor E. coli cause respiratory symptoms like those seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Bordetella pertussis produces several virulence factors that promote adhesion to cells, local tissue damage, and the impairment of phagocytosis. However, none of its exotoxins induce the activation of Gi-coupled protein receptors.
questions.hint: In an unvaccinated child, the symptoms of low-grade fever, intense paroxysms of cough followed by inspiratory stridor (whoop), posttussive emesis, and lymphocytosis are highly suggestive of whooping cough, an infection caused by Bordetella pertussis.
